name: Slippery Slope
definition: Claiming one action will inevitably lead to extreme consequences without showing how each step would actually happen.
whyItWorks: Fear is motivating. By painting a vivid worst-case scenario, we make even small changes seem dangerous. The chain of 'if...then' feels logical even when there's no proof each step will happen.

examples.text: If I let you borrow my notes once, you'll expect me to do all your work for you.
examples.analysis: Sharing notes once doesn't mean you'll become someone's personal tutor. You can help and still set limits.

examples.text: If your parents let you stay out until midnight once, next you'll want to stay out all night, and then you'll stop coming home at all.
examples.analysis: One later curfew doesn't automatically lead to no curfew. Most people can handle gradual trust without going to extremes.

examples.text: If we allow any path to legal status for undocumented immigrants, soon there will be no border at all.
examples.analysis: Many countries have paths to legal status without open borders. It assumes we can't set or keep limits.

examples.text: If we reduce sentences for non-violent drug offenses, violent crime will explode.
examples.analysis: Many places have reduced sentences without more violent crime. The chain of events isn't automatic.

examples.text: If the government can regulate one health supplement, they'll eventually ban all natural medicine.
examples.analysis: Requiring evidence for claims is different from banning products. Regulation exists on a spectrum.

examples.text: If we let teens question whether grades matter, soon no one will study and school will fall apart.
examples.analysis: Talking honestly about pressure doesn't mean giving up on learning. You can care about both well-being and effort.

examples.text: If we stop cancelling people for bad opinions, hate speech will take over everything.
examples.analysis: You can push back on harmful ideas in many ways. It's not guaranteed that less cancellation leads to total chaos.

examples.text: If you let one friend get away with a rude joke, soon they'll be bullying you every day.
examples.analysis: One unchallenged joke doesn't guarantee long-term bullying. It depends on how people respond over time.

examples.text: If we let landlords face any limits on rent, no one will build new housing and cities will die.
examples.analysis: Some regulation doesn't mean zero profit. There are many possible balances between profit and protection.

examples.text: If we allow this kind of political protest, soon there will be constant riots and the country will collapse.
examples.analysis: History shows protests can exist without society collapsing. It jumps from a small step to the worst outcome.

promptStarters: If we allow ___, soon we'll have ___, and eventually ___.
This is just the first step toward ___.
Once we start ___, where does it end?
Give them an inch on ___ and they'll take a mile.
